articles.headline: With the iPhone 6 Plus, Apple Aims for Versatility
articles.snippet: Clunky though the term may be, a phablet — part phone, part tablet — is a device that offers welcome versatility.
articles.abstract: Clunky though the term may be, a phablet — part phone, part tablet — is a device that offers welcome versatility.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time to make peace with the term phablet.

articles.headline: House Votes to Authorize Aid to Syrian Rebels in ISIS Fight
articles.snippet: A House divided along unusual and unpredictable lines voted to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels to confront the militant group Islamic State, backing President Obama.
articles.abstract: A House divided along unusual and unpredictable lines voted to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels to confront the militant group Islamic State, backing President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An unusual but overwhelming coalition in the House voted Wednesday to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels to confront the militant Islamic State, backing President Obama after he personally pleaded for support.

articles.headline: Fed Signals No Hurry to Raise Interest Rates
articles.snippet: Downgrading its economic forecasts, the Federal Reserve continued to say it would hold rates near zero for a “considerable time.”
articles.abstract: Downgrading its economic forecasts, the Federal Reserve continued to say it would hold rates near zero for a “considerable time.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is in no hurry to raise interest rates.

articles.headline: A Generation of Unintended Laughs
articles.snippet: “America’s Funniest Home Videos” turns 25, with YouTube a surprising part of its continued success.
articles.abstract: “America’s Funniest Home Videos” turns 25, with YouTube a surprising part of its continued success.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif. — “A relic of a bygone time.” “The uncoolest show on TV.” “Inexplicably never-ending, like a Cher farewell tour.”

articles.headline: Scottish Vote Weighs Pride Against Risk
articles.snippet: While Scots have been warned repeatedly about the dire consequences of voting for independence from the United Kingdom, half — more or less — are expected to do so anyway.
articles.abstract: While Scots have been warned repeatedly about the dire consequences of voting for independence from the United Kingdom, half — more or less — are expected to do so anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — The people of Scotland decide Thursday whether national pride outweighs economic risk.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Multinational Companies Court Lower-Income Consumers
articles.snippet: Companies once had little interest in lower-end consumers, but some now recognize the potential of that vast market.
articles.abstract: Companies once had little interest in lower-end consumers, but some now recognize the potential of that vast market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — When General Electric engineers here wanted to develop a more affordable baby warmer for India’s small, private hospitals, they initially replaced the fat, rubberized wheels standard on high-end models with smaller metal ones. They figured it was a quick, easy way to cut costs.

articles.headline: Gotham City, Emphasis on the Goth
articles.snippet: The new Fox drama “Gotham,” set in Batman’s city when Bruce Wayne was a boy, relies heavily on visual effects to create a setting out of time and place.
articles.abstract: The new Fox drama “Gotham,” set in Batman’s city when Bruce Wayne was a boy, relies heavily on visual effects to create a setting out of time and place.
articles.lead_paragraph: The star of “Gotham,” perhaps the most anticipated new drama of the television season, is not Batman, who probably won’t make an appearance (in that form) for the entire run of the series.

articles.headline: Obama Faulted in Terror Fight, New Poll Finds
articles.snippet: With Americans’ fears about a terrorist attack on the rise, a New York Times/CBS News poll finds the public is questioning President Obama’s strategy for combating the militant organization calling itself the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: With Americans’ fears about a terrorist attack on the rise, a New York Times/CBS News poll finds the public is questioning President Obama’s strategy for combating the militant organization calling itself the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in his presidency, more Americans disapprove of President Obama’s handling of terrorism than approve of it, as discontent about his management of foreign affairs and the fight against Sunni militants in Iraq and Syria weighs on an anxious and conflicted public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Dalia Sussman

articles.headline: F.T.C. Wary of Mergers by Hospitals
articles.snippet: Hospitals often say acquisitions are necessary to coordinate care, but the Federal Trade Commission says consolidation could increase consumer costs.
articles.abstract: Hospitals often say acquisitions are necessary to coordinate care, but the Federal Trade Commission says consolidation could increase consumer costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As hospitals merge and buy up physician practices, creating new behemoths, one federal agency is raising a lonely but powerful voice, suggesting that consumers may be victimized by the trend toward consolidation.

articles.headline: Five Years Later, Chrysler’s Gamble on Ram Trucks Is Paying Off
articles.snippet: The Ram truck division is increasing market share with an emphasis on fuel economy and upgraded interiors.
articles.abstract: The Ram truck division is increasing market share with an emphasis on fuel economy and upgraded interiors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — In December, the sprawling, four million-square-foot factory here where workers assemble Ram pickup trucks, along conveyors that weave for more than 30 miles, suddenly went quiet.

articles.headline: Surrogates and Couples Face a Maze of Laws, State by State
articles.snippet: There is nothing resembling a national consensus on how to handle surrogacy and no federal law, leaving the states free to do as they wish.
articles.abstract: There is nothing resembling a national consensus on how to handle surrogacy and no federal law, leaving the states free to do as they wish.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Crystal Kelley, a Connecticut woman who had signed a contract to bear a baby for a couple in her state, was five months pregnant, a routine ultrasound showed that the fetus had a cleft palate, a brain cyst and heart defects. The couple for whom she was carrying the baby asked her to have an abortion, offering to pay her $10,000 to do so.

articles.headline: Sicilian Town on Migrants’ Route Cares for the Living and the Dead
articles.snippet: Italy has staggered its way through a skyrocketing migration crisis in the Mediterranean that has seen roughly 120,000 migrants rescued by Italian ships this year, while nearly 2,800 have died in shipwrecks or in transit.
articles.abstract: Italy has staggered its way through a skyrocketing migration crisis in the Mediterranean that has seen roughly 120,000 migrants rescued by Italian ships this year, while nearly 2,800 have died in shipwrecks or in transit.
articles.lead_paragraph: POZZALLO, Sicily — The 18 coffins were placed in two neat rows beneath the late-afternoon sun as the mayor and other dignitaries took their seats inside the hilltop cemetery. A Catholic vicar-general offered a homily. A Muslim imam unfurled a small rug and knelt in prayer, his singsong voice rising above the stone mausoleums toward the blue of the Mediterranean.

articles.headline: Scotland Rejects Independence From United Kingdom
articles.snippet: The outcome headed off the political, economic and military imponderables that would have accompanied a divorce from the United Kingdom.
articles.abstract: The outcome headed off the political, economic and military imponderables that would have accompanied a divorce from the United Kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Voters in Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum that had threatened to break up the 307-year union between them, according to projections by the BBC and Sky News early Friday.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Alan Cowell
